data.event: Assistant public defender Benjamin Pearlman is arguing that, after a one-day civil trial last fall, a jury contradicted a state psychologist's finding that Steven Anthony Eberhart is incompetent.

event.title: argued in documents filed last month

data.event: Pearlman keeps in contact with the staff at East Central Regional Hospital, and every specialist involved in treating Eberhart "continues to have the opinion that he is still not competent to stand trial," Pearlman argued in documents filed last month in Clarke County Superior Court.

event.title: attacked Sgt. Courtney Gale with a kitchen knife on Dec. 11, 2007

data.event: Authorities say Eberhart, 45, attacked Sgt. Courtney Gale with a kitchen knife on Dec. 11, 2007, repeatedly stabbing the uniformed officer as she worked an off-duty security guard job in the Kroger store on Alps Road.
Gale spent two weeks in a coma, had several surgeries to save one of her legs and went through extensive physical and cognitive rehabilitation.

event.title: murder charge and 10 other felonies, and in September

data.event: A grand jury indicted Eberhart on a criminal attempt to commit murder charge and 10 other felonies, and in September, a civil panel in Clarke County Superior Court determined that Eberhart, though he has a history of schizophrenia, is competent to stand trial.
Eberhart has been held at the Augusta psychiatric hospital since soon after his arrest in December 2007.
He couldn't attend his own arraignment hearing Feb. 4, so the court entered a not guilty plea on his behalf.
Pearlman already asked the state Court of Appeals to overturn the competency decision, but the court dismissed the appeal in December, stating it lacked jurisdiction.
